quoteFirst: Arrived at the river Sobat junction at
quoteLast: , and anchored about half a mile within that river at a spot where the Turks had formerly constructed a camp. Not a tree to be seen; but dead flats of prairie and marsh as far as the eye can reach.
title: The Albert N'Yanza, Great Basin of the Nile, And Explorations of the Nile Sources

quoteLast: the squadron returned and anchored off Manila, the _Petrel_ being left behind to complete the destruction of the smaller gunboats, which were behind the point of Cavite. This duty was performed by Commander E. P. Wood in the most expeditious and complete manner possible.
title: The Boys of '98

quoteFirst: Arrived at the river Sobat junction at
quoteLast: , and anchored about half a mile within that river at a spot where the Turks had formerly constructed a camp. Not a tree to be seen; but dead flats of prairie and marsh as far as the eye can reach.

quoteFirst: But though the guns now stood unprotected on the open veld, save for the handful of gunners, Devon, and Scots Fusiliers left in the donga in rear, the Boers feared a trap, and could not at first realise their good fortune. A telegram despatched at
quoteLast: , by Botha to Pretoria had reported that "we cannot go and fetch the guns, as the enemy command the bridge with their artillery." When the Naval battery had been withdrawn the burghers ventured across the river and made prisoners of the party in the donga, Colonel Bullock making a sturdy resistance to the last.
title:
History of the War in South Africa 1899-1902 v. 1 (of 4)
Compiled by Direction of His Majesty's Government
author: Great Britain. War Office; Maurice, John Frederick, 1841-1912 [Compiler]

quoteFirst: From camp we crossed a bad gully and from it made a fair start at 11.52, having made at that place half a mile south-west by south. The river is at this place closely confined on both sides by stony ranges; a few drops of rain fell on us in that pass. At
quoteLast: made two miles west to a small dry watercourse from the north, which is full of pandanus at its mouth. The ranges on the left bank had on them dykes like artificial ones, which run at different places across the hills.
title: Journal of Landsborough's expedition from Carpentaria, in search of Burke & Wills
author: Landsborough, William, 1825-1886

quoteLast: I was driving Marsalis Bus No.

quoteFirst: It became much cooler and more pure and refreshing, and all went along at a faster rate and with lighter hearts. Now that the Zanzibaris had come so far, they all appeared anxious to ascend as high as possible, and began to chaff each other as to who should bring down the biggest load of the “white stuff” on the top of the mountain. At
quoteLast: we emerged from the bamboos and sat down on a grassy spot to eat our lunch. Barometers, 21·10 and 27·95/100. Thermometer, 70° F.
title: In Darkest Africa, Vol. 2; or, The Quest, Rescue, and Retreat of Emin, Governor of Equatoria
author: Stanley, Henry M. (Henry Morton), 1841-1904
